response.answer_text: The other answers so far have missed the most important point by far. The real importance of Cleopatra is that she is an outstanding example of a woman who achieved great importance in ancient times without merely being a power behind the throne. The ancient world being what it is, her destiny was wrapped up closely with her dealings with men… therefore, she cannot be called a perfect proto-feminist in every respect. She came to the sole occupation of the Throne of Egypt by appealing to, and seducing, Julius Caesar, who (with powerful legions at his back) had given himself power to decide Egyptian dynastic issues. Later, she allied with Mark Antony… again, by seducing him… in an attempt to put her own son, Caesarion, in line for leadership of the whole Roman Empire. That attempt dramatically failed, but still… No matter how much her destiny was intertwined with men, she nonetheless acted as a kind of free agent, acting on her own ambitions, concocting plans, making her own bid for power. That had never happened before in classical times, except in legend. Prior to Cleo, both early Greek women and early Roman women were praised, if they were praised at all, for their humility, obedience, modesty, and chastity. And woman who ever got the idea she could act like a consul or even a senator would’ve quickly been put in her place… and a man raised his daughters to know that. A curious thing happened in later times, however. As the Emperors grew powerful beyond measure, sometimes their wives could become powerful by (in effect) ruling the ruler. For example, Messalina could’ve asked anything of Emperor Claudius, and he would’ve granted it. Only when it was revealed that she was plotting against him with her lover did Claudius turn against her and agree to sign a death warrant. In any case, women in this society could become very powerful and influential by marrying just the right man. But they could not become rulers in their own right. It was to be many centuries before women in Europe won the right to rule in their own names… as in the early Middle Ages when King Stephen and Queen Margaret battled for control of England. Oh, and by the way, the reputation of Cleo does not rest on Will Shakespeare alone, as great as he was… nor even does the reputation of Julius Caesar. Caesar and Cleo simply loomed far too large in history for even as great writer as Shakespeare to have “made” them. I think it’s fair to say, however, that Shakes probably enhanced her reputation somewhat, as in this great quotation from Act II, scene II of “Antony and Cleopatra”: Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale her infinite variety…
